meta.v: Vicente, Gil. Copilaçam de todalas obras de Gil Vicente, a qual se reparte em cinco liuros. Lixboa: em casa de Ioam Aluavez, 1562. CCXLIX f., il.
Compilaçam de todalas obras de Gil Vicente.
Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal; Fac-simile provided at http://www.purl.pt/11494

Vicente, Gil. Auto Pastoril Português; Auto da Feira; Barca do Inferno; Purgatório (barca segunda); Tragicomédia da Serra da Estrela; Romagem dos Agravados; Quem tem farelos? Online edition by José Camões. http://www.cet-e-quinhentos.com
Centro de Estudos de Teatro, Universidade de Lisboa

w.f: mil quinhentos e vinte e três

w.comment: 'Enha' is used in Gil Vicente for 'minha'.
A line break was inserted here. In the original this and the following verse appear together.

On the period of oblivion of this artist, see "Historia do theatro portuguez: Vida de Gil Vicente e sua escola, século XVI" p. 48ff, by Teophilo Braga, who interprets that 'jo' is 'já'. Here we follow the CET-UL edition, which is based on the metrics of the verse, which forces an ellipsis of 'nome'.
A stanza break appeared here, in the original.
Same as 'rarearão' ('rarear' in future indicative, 3p plural)
The following verses are a translation of the hymn "laudes" from the "Hours of Our Lady", attributed to Venancio Fortunato (see CET-UL edition).

w.f: mil quinhentos e vinte e sete

w.comment: Probably this word is not part of the verse, otherwise it will be hypermetric.
Johan Müller (Regiomontanus) (1436-1476), astronomer from Königsberg (from the CET Edition).
'= Medina do Campo', a big fair in the Iberian Peninsula in the 16th century.
In the original, the verse includes: 'e nam vos embaraceis nem torvês'.
In the context, purgatório should be understood as 'inferno'.
= parte inferior da vela de um barco.
'adriça' - cabo com que se iça as vergas do navio.
'vossa' is changed to 'nossa' according to the 1517 edition.
'Oulá' is preferred instead of 'hou' because of the metrics and comparing to the 1517 edition (see CET-UL edition).

w.f: mil quinhentos e cinquenta e oito

w.comment: Proverb - Reference to the episode 'Cerco de Zamora' a chapter in the history of Castilla and Leon, around the year 1072, with doubtful historical authenticity (cf. interpretation in 'Estudos sobre o romanceiro peninsular - o romance velho em Portugal', by Carolina Michaelis de Vasconcelos, p. 48).
In the CET-UL edition the writing 'douche' is maintained so as to permit the double reading 'dou-te' and 'doce'.
this verse does not show the expected rhyme between 'levar' e 'comer'.
'sanctificetur' = reference to the Lord's Prayer (sanctificetur nomen tuum).
corruption of an excerpt of 'Hail Mary': "benedictus fructus ventris".
The original does not include the preposition; however, the metrics and syntax require it.
The question mark was not present in the original text.
'Filha de Príamo, por quem Aquiles se apaixonou'.
The stanza ends here, but once the sentence continues until the next verse, it appears together with this stanza.

p.comment: Na versão original da peça o trecho é o seguinte: "Dia. Olhay flores nam meſpanto que me digaes ſete tanto padeça meu coração. ¶O por vir & o preſente ſenhora por concruſam, nam quero de vos ſoomente ſenam dardeſme eſſa mão ſe diſſo fordes contente. (...)" No entanto, tomando como base a edição proposta por José Camões, do corpus do Centro de Estudos de Teatro, Teatro de Autores Portugueses do Séc. XVI (www.cet-e-quinhentos.com), em que o editor levou em consideração a escanção do poema, decidiu-se segmentar a segunda sentença e unir "¶O por vir & o preſente" como sendo parte da sentença anterior.

Na versão original esta sentença "vos eſtais muyto garrido, tirar vos hão dom perdido dos olhos a marmeluta." continua a fala do Menino. Porém, tomando como base para edição a edição de José Camões, do corpus do Centro de Estudos de Teatro, Teatro de Autores Portugueses do Séc. XVI (www.cet-e-quinhentos.com), decidiu-se por quebrar a sentença e marcar a segunda parte como sendo fala do Diabo.

w.f: mil quinhentos e vinte e sete

w.comment: Reference to the birth of Filipe II, that would spouse infanta Maria. Empenatriz refers to Imperatriz.
These verses lack rhyme, maybe a consequence of a change in their order.
This verse appears together with the previous one, in the original.
Reference to D. João III, born in 1502. In the honor of his birth, Gil Vicente makes represent his first play in 1502 - see CET-UL edition.
D. Catarina, regent queen during the minority of D. Sebastião.
D. Maria was born in a Tuesday. (The day of Mars, according to the pagan calendar.)
corruption of the latin expression 'dominus tecum' (~'Deus [esteja] contigo).
In the original these verses are attributed to Felipa, but this cannot be correct, from the context.
reference to the suicide of Dido, the first queen of Carthage.
An excerpt of the pater noster: 'sed libera nos a malo'.
In the original these verses are attributed to Caterina, but from the context they must have been pronounced by Felipa.
Possible adaptation from the anonymous verses 'Tales ollos como los vosos/ nan os hay en Portugal...' commpiled by Juan Vásquez in "Recopilación de sonetos y villancicos" II, 41.

This song is built on a frequent theme in "cantigas de amigo". Cf. Juan Vásquez's Recopilación de sonetos y villancicos II, 32: 'No me firáis madre / Yo os lo diré: / mal d'amores é...' (cf. CET-UL edition).

w.f: mil quinhentos e trinta e três

w.comment: This play was eliminated in the Compilaçam dated of 1586. (Cf. CET-UL edition)
As noted in the CET-UL edition, this seems to be a hypermetric verse; possibly it should be changed to 'Chove quando não quero'.
This is a hypermetric verse, an alternative is: 'No latim te quero ver' (see CET-UL edition).
'blessed man', the beggining of many Psalms.
According to the original, this would be the continuation of Bastião's turn, but the meaning implied by these verses lead us to attribute them to João da Mortinheira (see CET-UL edition).
De Sibilas, i.e. onde elas moram.
This sentence break is not present in the original.
Semi-colon not present in the original.

From the responsorial excerpt to the 4th lesson of the 2nd nocturne of the Office of the Dead, in Latin: "Memento mei Deus, quia ventus est vita mea..." (Remember, God, that my life is a blast) (cf. Job 1,1 and Psalms 130, 1-2 - from the CET-UL edition).
According to the CET-UL edition, this sould be 'enterramento', but this is not clear given the context.
The meaning of the play suggests that it should be Hilária, and not Juliana, who takes the turn here. This has consequences for the following turns.
See Novel of the Prisioner (Cancionero Musical de Palacio, f. 56ss.).

sc.comment: Na versão original deste texto o autor utilizou um sinal de pontuação antigo que possuía a mesma função do ponto de interrogação. Sendo assim, devido a impossibilidade de inserir o sinal, na transcrição do texto foi utilizado o ponto de interrogação ( ? ).

w.comment: This is a hipometric verse. It should be 'Hi hi hi hi hi hi hi'.
Old currency, which corresponds to a fourth part of a maravedi.
Reference to Hannibal, captain of Carthage.
Reference to Corneius Scipio, Roman General of the 2nd Punic war, who defeated Hannibal in the battle of Zama.
Reference to the battle of Roncesvales, when Charlemagne was defeated.
In the original, Aires, the squire name.
The meaning of text suggests that it should be Apariço, and not Ordoño, here (see CET-UL edition).
In the original, Aires, the squire name.
This turn is attributed in the original to Apariço, but the meaning requires it to be the Squire (o Escudeiro).
The correction into 'fruito' is necessary because of the rhyme.
In the original, we find: "Que são que são", but this rendering woud make it extrametric.
Although the original presents "Doute oo", a contraction is needed so as to secure the metric of the verse.
Following the CET-UL edition, we have inserted a verse break here, because with the vocative the following words make the verse extrametric.
The meaning here made us correct the sequence "em fiar" into "enfiar".
trintário; mass after the first month from the death of someone; or a set of 30 masses.
First verse of the 'Novel of the Prisioner', in Spanish.
Hypermetric verse, a solution is "ò demo dou a criança".
A pray attributed to Saint Ignatius of Loyola: "Anima Christi, santifica me / Corpus Christi salva me..."
In the original, the rest of this stanza is attributed to the Old woman (Velha), and this indication does not exist (see CET-UL edition).
